cards.front: State Parseval's theorem for the Fourier Series.
cards.back:
P_avg = (1/T₀)∫|x(t)|²dt = Σ_{k=−∞}^{∞} |X_k|²

Total average power = sum of squared magnitudes of all FS coefficients.
The power contribution of the k-th harmonic to the total signal power. Each harmonic carries its own independent power, and Parseval's says they all add up.

cards.front: For real signals, simplify the Parseval's summation.
cards.back:
P = |X₀|² + 2·Σ_{k=1}^{∞} |X_k|²

Because |X_{−k}| = |X_k| for real signals, each k>0 contributes twice (for +k and −k).

cards.front: How can Parseval's theorem serve as a sanity check?
cards.back:
Compute power two ways:
1. Time domain: P = (1/T₀)∫|x(t)|²dt
2. Frequency domain: P = Σ|X_k|²

If they don't match, your FS coefficients are wrong.

cards.front: Outline the key step in deriving Parseval's theorem.
cards.back: Substitute FS for x(t) in (1/T₀)∫x(t)·x*(t)dt. The orthogonality of basis functions makes all cross-terms (k ≠ m) vanish, leaving only Σ|X_k|².

cards.front: Why are periodic signals called 'power signals'?
cards.back: They have finite average power but infinite total energy (since they extend to ±∞). Power = energy per period, which is finite.

cards.front: How does Parseval's theorem help estimate bandwidth?
cards.back:
Truncate to N harmonics: P_N = Σ_{k=−N}^{N} |X_k|².
Compare P_N/P_total. If P_10/P = 0.99, then 10 harmonics capture 99% of power → essential bandwidth ≈ 10ω₀.
The set of values {|X_k|²} for all k. It shows how power is distributed across harmonic frequencies. The sum of all values equals the total average power (Parseval's).
